message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: An Overview of Recent Advances in Coordinated Control of Multiple Autonomous Surface Vehicles
Paper Abstract: Autonomous surface vehicles (ASVs) are marine vessels capable of performing various marine operations without a crew in a variety of cluttered and hostile water/ocean environments. For complex missions, there are increasing needs for deploying a fleet of ASVs instead of a single one to complete difficult tasks. Cooperative operations with a fleet of ASVs offer great advantages with enhanced capability and efficacy. Despite various application potentials, coordinated motion control of ASVs pose great challenges due to the multiplicity of ASVs, complexity of intravehicle interactions and fleet formation with collision avoidance requirements, and scarcity of communication bandwidths in sea environments. Coordinated control of multiple ASVs has received considerable attention in the last decade. This article provides an overview of recent advances in coordinated control of multiple ASVs. First, some challenging issues and scenarios in motion control of ASVs are presented. Next, coordinated control architecture and methods of multiple ASVs are briefly discussed. Then, recent results on trajectory-guided, path-guided, and target-guided coordinated control of multiple ASVs are reviewed in detail. Finally, several theoretical and technical issues are suggested to direct future investigations including network-based coordination, event-triggered coordination, collision-free coordination, optimization-based coordination, data-driven coordination of ASVs, and task-region-oriented coordination of multiple ASVs and autonomous underwater vehicles.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of motion control:

## Definition

Motion control is a sub-field of automation, encompassing the systems or sub-systems involved in moving parts of machines in a controlled manner.

## Industrial Applications

Motion control systems are extensively used in a variety of fields for automation purposes, including precision engineering, micromanufacturing, biotechnology, and nanotechnology.(no content)Motion control is widely used in the packaging, printing, textile, semiconductor production, and assembly industries.

## System Architecture

The main components involved typically include a motion controller, an energy amplifier, and one or more prime movers or actuators.(no content)Typically the position or velocity of machines are controlled using some type of device such as a hydraulic pump, linear actuator, or electric motor, generally a servo.

## Control Types

Motion control may be open loop or closed loop. In open loop systems, the controller sends a command through the amplifier to the prime mover or actuator, and does not know if the desired motion was actually achieved.

## Other Applications

Beyond industrial automation, motion control also has applications in:
- Motion control photography, a technique used in still and motion photography that enables precise control of, and optionally also allows repetition of, camera movements. It can be used to facilitate special effects photography.
- In computing, motion controllers are input devices that use accelerometers, gyroscopes, cameras, or other sensors to track motion.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of motion control:

## Definition

Motion control is a sub-field of automation, encompassing the systems or sub-systems involved in moving parts of machines in a controlled manner.

## Industrial Applications

Motion control systems are extensively used in a variety of fields for automation purposes, including precision engineering, micromanufacturing, biotechnology, and nanotechnology.(no content)Motion control is widely used in the packaging, printing, textile, semiconductor production, and assembly industries.

## System Architecture

The main components involved typically include a motion controller, an energy amplifier, and one or more prime movers or actuators.(no content)Typically the position or velocity of machines are controlled using some type of device such as a hydraulic pump, linear actuator, or electric motor, generally a servo.

## Control Types

Motion control may be open loop or closed loop. In open loop systems, the controller sends a command through the amplifier to the prime mover or actuator, and does not know if the desired motion was actually achieved.

## Other Applications

Beyond industrial automation, motion control also has applications in:
- Motion control photography, a technique used in still and motion photography that enables precise control of, and optionally also allows repetition of, camera movements. It can be used to facilitate special effects photography.
- In computing, motion controllers are input devices that use accelerometers, gyroscopes, cameras, or other sensors to track motion.

Web search results for query: "coordinated control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Traffic light control and coordination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Traffic_light_control_and_coordination"},{"title":"Motion control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_control"},{"title":"Hierarchical control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_control_system"},{"title":"Collaborative Control Theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_Control_Theory"},{"title":"Distributed control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_control_system"},{"title":"Industrial process control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_process_control"},{"title":"Management control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Management_control_system"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about coordinated control systems:

## Overview

Coordinated control systems refer to control architectures where multiple controllers or components work together in a synchronized manner to achieve desired objectives. There are several key aspects:

### Decentralized Coordination

When systems are controlled by multiple controllers, it becomes a decentralized control problem where agents can interact using communication channels and coordinate their actions.(no content)Decentralization is helpful in many ways, for instance, it helps control systems to operate over a larger geographical area.

### Motion Control Applications

The interface between the motion controller and drives it controls is very critical when coordinated motion is required, as it must provide tight synchronization, with early open interfaces like SERCOS (developed in 1991) enabling coordinated motion control.

### Traffic Control Example

A practical example is traffic light coordination. Coordinated (progressed) systems are controlled from a master controller and are set up so lights "cascade" (progress) in sequence so platoons of vehicles can proceed through a continuous series of green lights.

### Collaborative Control Theory

Collaborative Control Theory (CCT) is a collection of principles and models for supporting the effective design of collaborative e-Work systems, enabled by advances in information and communications technologies, artificial intelligence, multi-agent systems, and cyber-physical systems in highly distributed organizations of people, robots, and autonomous systems.

Coordinated control systems are fundamental to modern automation across manufacturing, transportation, and distributed industrial processes.

I've performed a web search on "collision avoidance" and found comprehensive information across multiple domains. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Collision avoidance in transportation is the maintenance of systems and practices designed to prevent vehicles (such as aircraft, motor vehicles, ships, cranes and trains) from colliding with each other.

## Applications by Domain

**Aviation:**
A traffic alert and collision avoidance system (TCAS), also known as an Airborne Collision Avoidance System (ACAS), is an aircraft collision avoidance system designed to reduce the incidence of mid-air collision (MAC) between aircraft.(no content)It is mandated by the International Civil Aviation Organization to be fitted to all aircraft with a maximum take-off mass (MTOM) of over 5,700 kg (12,600 lb) or authorized to carry more than 19 passengers.

**Automotive:**
A collision avoidance system (CAS), also known as a pre-crash system, forward collision warning system (FCW), or collision mitigation system, is an advanced driver-assistance system designed to prevent or reduce the severity of a collision.(no content)When the collision becomes imminent, they can take action autonomously without any driver input (by braking or steering or both).

**Maritime:**
Maritime Collision Avoidance Systems (MCAS) are integrated technologies used to prevent collisions and groundings at sea by enhancing vessel situational awareness.(no content)These systems combine data from multiple onboard sensors such as radar, AIS, GPS, sonar, and compass, with real-time processing algorithms, often employing artificial intelligence.

**Networking:**
In computer networking and telecommunication, collision-avoidance methods try to avoid resource contention by attempting to avoid simultaneous attempts to access the same resource.

**Spacecraft:**
Spacecraft collision avoidance is the implementation and study of processes minimizing the chance of orbiting spacecraft inadvertently colliding with other orbiting objects.

Links: [{"title":"Autonomous underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"Vityaz-D Autonomous Underwater Vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vityaz-D_Autonomous_Underwater_Vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned underwater vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_underwater_vehicle"},{"title":"AUV-150 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AUV-150"},{"title":"Category:Autonomous underwater vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Autonomous_underwater_vehicles"},{"title":"Sentry (AUV) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentry_(AUV)"},{"title":"REMUS (vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/REMUS_(vehicle)"},{"title":"Theseus (AUV) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theseus_(AUV)"},{"title":"Maya AUV India - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maya_AUV_India"},{"title":"Explorer AUV - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explorer_AUV"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about autonomous underwater vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs constitute part of a larger group of undersea systems known as unmanned underwater vehicles, a classification that includes non-autonomous remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs)  controlled and powered from the surface by an operator/pilot via an umbilical or using remote control.

## History

The first AUV was developed at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington as early as 1957 by Stan Murphy, Bob Francois and later on, Terry Ewart. The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

## Navigation and Sensors

AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean. Typical sensors include compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, so as soon as an AUV dives it loses its GPS signal. Therefore, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

## Power Systems

Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

## Applications

Autonomous underwater vehicles, for example AUV ABYSS, have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, e.g. Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about autonomous underwater vehicles:

## Definition and Overview

An autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV) is a robot that travels underwater without requiring continuous input from an operator.(no content)AUVs constitute part of a larger group of undersea systems known as unmanned underwater vehicles, a classification that includes non-autonomous remotely operated underwater vehicles (ROVs)  controlled and powered from the surface by an operator/pilot via an umbilical or using remote control.

## History

The first AUV was developed at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington as early as 1957 by Stan Murphy, Bob Francois and later on, Terry Ewart. The "Self-Propelled Underwater Research Vehicle", or SPURV, was used to study diffusion, acoustic transmission, and submarine wakes.

## Navigation and Sensors

AUVs carry sensors to navigate autonomously and map features of the ocean. Typical sensors include compasses, depth sensors, sidescan and other sonars, magnetometers, thermistors and conductivity probes.(no content)Radio waves cannot penetrate water very far, so as soon as an AUV dives it loses its GPS signal. Therefore, a standard way for AUVs to navigate underwater is through dead reckoning.

## Power Systems

Most AUVs in use today are powered by rechargeable batteries (lithium ion, lithium polymer, nickel metal hydride etc.), and are implemented with some form of battery management system.

## Applications

Autonomous underwater vehicles, for example AUV ABYSS, have been used to find wreckage of missing airplanes, e.g. Air France Flight 447, and the Bluefin-21 AUV was used in the search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

Web search results for query: "autonomous surface vehicle"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned surface vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_surface_vehicle"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned surface vehicles of the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_surface_vehicles_of_the_United_States"},{"title":"UAPS20 Unmanned AutoPilot System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UAPS20_Unmanned_AutoPilot_System"},{"title":"Spindle (vehicle) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spindle_(vehicle)"},{"title":"Hilairy Hartnett - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilairy_Hartnett"},{"title":"Category:Unmanned surface vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Unmanned_surface_vehicles"}]

Here are the search results for "autonomous surface vehicle":

## Overview

An autonomous surface vehicle is a boat or ship that operates on the surface of the water without a crew.(no content)These vehicles operate with various levels of autonomy, from remote control to fully autonomous surface vehicles (ASV). They're also known as unmanned surface vessels (USV), uncrewed surface vessels, or colloquially as "drone boats" or "sea drones."

## Applications

Autonomous surface vehicles have diverse applications across multiple sectors:

- **Hydrographic Survey**: The ASV Global 'C-Worker 5' autonomous surface vehicle collected 2,275 nautical miles of survey in the Bering Sea off Alaska, resulting in a saving of 25 days at sea.

- **Environmental Monitoring**: Saildrones are a type of uncrewed surface vehicle used primarily in oceans for data collection and are wind and solar powered.

- **Scientific Research**: The Mayflower AI sea drone project is sending an autonomous vehicle across the Atlantic Ocean to collect scientific data about the state of the surface ocean.

- **Urban Waterways**: In 2021, the world's first urban autonomous vessels, Roboats, were deployed in Amsterdam's canals and could carry up to five people, collect waste, deliver goods, monitor the environment and provide on-demand infrastructure.

## Military Applications

In January 2024, TCB Marlin entered service in the Turkish Naval Forces as the first armed USV. Additionally, in 2024, Sagar Defence Engineering demonstrated an 850 nautical mile autonomous transit of the Matangi Autonomous Surface Vessel to the Indian Navy as part of India's Swavalamban 2024 self-reliance in technology contest.

Links: [{"title":"Time-triggered architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-triggered_architecture"},{"title":"Discrete-event dynamic system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discrete_event_dynamic_system"},{"title":"Time-Triggered Protocol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time-Triggered_Protocol"},{"title":"Maurice Heemels - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Heemels"},{"title":"Industrial control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_control_system"},{"title":"Event-driven architecture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_architecture"},{"title":"Event (computing) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Keystrokes"},{"title":"Event-driven programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event_driven_programming"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Event-driven process chain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Event-driven_process_chain"}]

Based on the search results, I found several relevant concepts related to event-triggered control systems:

## Key Information

Event-triggered systems are a recognized area of control engineering research, with significant contributions in their analysis and design. While the search results don't provide a specific definition of event-triggered control systems, they offer related concepts:

**Related Control System Concepts:**

A discrete-event dynamic system (DEDS) is a discrete-state, event-driven system of which the state evolution depends entirely on the occurrence of asynchronous discrete events over time.

**Time-Triggered vs. Event-Triggered:**

The results also discuss an alternative approach: Time-triggered architecture (abbreviated as TTA), also known as a time-triggered system, is a computer system that executes one or more sets of tasks according to a predetermined and set task schedule.

**Event-Driven Programming Fundamentals:**

In general event-driven systems, there is generally an event loop that listens for events and then triggers a callback function when one of those events is detected.

## Summary

Event-triggered control systems represent an approach where control actions are initiated based on specific events occurring in the system, rather than on a fixed time schedule. This contrasts with time-triggered systems that operate on predetermined schedules. The field has gained significant academic attention and is an active area of control engineering research.

I've completed the web search for "trajectory planning control". Here are the key results:

## Overview

Web search results for query: "path planning navigation"

Links: [{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning"},{"title":"Any-angle path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Any-angle_path_planning"},{"title":"Real-time path planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_path_planning"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Navigation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_function"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Obstacle avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Obstacle_avoidance"},{"title":"Multi-agent pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_pathfinding"},{"title":"Navigation mesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_mesh"}]

I found comprehensive information about path planning and navigation. Here's an overview of what the search results cover:

## Path Planning Overview

Path planning navigation involves functions of position, velocity, acceleration and time which are used to plan robot trajectories through the environment.(no content)Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

## Key Approaches

**Grid-Based Methods**: Grid-based approaches overlay a grid on configuration space and assume each configuration is identified with a grid point. However, traditional grid-based approaches produce paths whose heading changes are constrained to multiples of a given base angle, often resulting in suboptimal paths.

**Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle. The result is a path that cuts directly through open areas and has relatively few turns.

**Sampling-Based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces, and have been applied to problems which have dozens or even hundreds of dimensions.

## Popular Algorithms

Popular path-planning algorithms include A* (A-star), Dijkstra's algorithm, and Rapidly-exploring Random Trees (RRT).

## Navigation Meshes

A navigation mesh, or navmesh, is an abstract data structure used in artificial intelligence applications to aid agents in pathfinding through complicated spaces.

Here are the search results for "network control systems":

## Key Results

**Networked Control Systems (NCS)**

A networked control system (NCS) is a control system wherein the control loops are closed through a communication network.(no content)The defining feature of an NCS is that control and feedback signals are exchanged among the system's components in the form of information packages through a network.

**Characteristics and Challenges**

The insertion of the communication network in the feedback control loop makes the analysis and design of an NCS complex, since it imposes additional time delays in control loops or possibility of packages loss.(no content)New control strategies, kinematics of the actuators in the systems, reliability and security of communications, bandwidth allocation, development of data communication protocols, corresponding fault detection and fault tolerant control strategies, real-time information collection and efficient processing of sensors data are some of the relative topics studied in depth.

**Related Systems**

The search results also covered related control system types:
- A distributed control system (DCS) is a computerized control system for a process or plant usually with many control loops, in which autonomous controllers are distributed throughout the system, but there is no central operator supervisory control, which is in contrast to systems that use centralized controllers.

The results included various specific implementations such as IP access controllers, flight control systems, and intelligent control techniques using neural networks and machine learning.

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Linearquadratic regulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linearquadratic_regulator"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"DIDO (software) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DIDO_(software)"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Trajectory optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trajectory_optimization"},{"title":"Simulation-based optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simulation-based_optimization"}]

I've successfully performed a web search for "optimization control systems." Here's what I found:

## Key Findings

**Definition and Core Concept:**
Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved.(no content)A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables, and an optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.

**Main Approaches:**
The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle or by solving the HamiltonJacobiBellman equation. Additionally, two optimal control design methods have been widely used in industrial applications: Model Predictive Control (MPC) and linear-quadratic-Gaussian control (LQG).

**Practical Applications:**
Optimal control is a particular control technique in which the control signal optimizes a certain "cost index": for example, in the case of a satellite, the jet thrusts needed to bring it to desired trajectory that consume the least amount of fuel.

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about formation control robotics:

Formation control of robotic systems is a research area known for its work in the control of groups of robots moving together. This field is particularly associated with researchers like M. Anthony Lewis, who has made significant contributions to understanding how multiple robots can be coordinated to maintain specific spatial arrangements.

Magnus Egerstedt, a prominent roboticist, has made major contributions to the theory of the control of multi-agent systems, which is closely related to formation control. Egerstedt launched the Robotarium, a swarm-robotic research testbed whose goal is to provide access to a state-of-the-art test facility to researchers around the globe.

Formation control is part of the broader field of robotics and control theory, where disciplines contributing to robotics include electrical, control, software, information, electronic, telecommunication, computer, mechatronic, and materials engineering.

The search results indicate that formation control is an active area of research in robotics, focusing on coordinating multiple robotic agents to work together in organized patterns, though the results don't provide extensive technical details about specific formation control methodologies or algorithms.

I've completed the web search for "multi-agent systems coordination." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Coordination Mechanisms

Agent actions are typically mediated via an appropriate middleware that offers a first-class design abstraction for multi-agent systems, providing means to govern resource access and agent coordination.(no content)In computer science multi-agent planning involves coordinating the resources and activities of multiple agents.(no content)This can involve agents planning for a common goal, an agent coordinating the plans or planning of others, or agents refining their own plans while negotiating over tasks or resources.

## Communication and Collaboration

When agents can share knowledge using any agreed language within the constraints of the system's communication protocol, the approach may lead to a common improvement, with example languages being Knowledge Query Manipulation Language (KQML) or Agent Communication Language (ACL).

## Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Real-World Applications

Applications include transportation, logistics, graphics, manufacturing, power systems, smartgrids, and GIS.

I've performed a web search for "machine learning data-driven control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Data-driven control systems are a broad family of control systems, in which the identification of the process model and/or the design of the controller are based entirely on experimental data collected from the plant.

## Key Approaches

**Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP):** The core idea revolves around learning a control policy that minimizes a long-term cost function, and ADP has been applied to robotics, power systems, and autonomous vehicles, offering a data-driven framework for near-optimal control without requiring full system models.

**Direct Data-Driven Methods:** Direct data-driven methods allow tuning a controller, belonging to a given class, without the need of an identified model of the system.(no content)The iterative feedback tuning (IFT) method was introduced in 1994, and noniterative correlation-based tuning (nCbT) is a noniterative method for data-driven tuning of a fixed-structure controller that provides a one-shot method to directly synthesize a controller based on a single dataset.

## Intelligent Control Integration

Intelligent control is a class of control techniques that use various artificial intelligence computing approaches like neural networks, Bayesian probability, fuzzy logic, machine learning, reinforcement learning, evolutionary computation and genetic algorithms.

The search results show that machine learning and data-driven control represent important complementary approaches that reduce reliance on detailed mathematical models by leveraging experimental data and AI techniques.

I've performed a web search for "machine learning data-driven control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Data-driven control systems are a broad family of control systems, in which the identification of the process model and/or the design of the controller are based entirely on experimental data collected from the plant.

## Key Approaches

**Adaptive Dynamic Programming (ADP):** The core idea revolves around learning a control policy that minimizes a long-term cost function, and ADP has been applied to robotics, power systems, and autonomous vehicles, offering a data-driven framework for near-optimal control without requiring full system models.

**Direct Data-Driven Methods:** Direct data-driven methods allow tuning a controller, belonging to a given class, without the need of an identified model of the system.(no content)The iterative feedback tuning (IFT) method was introduced in 1994, and noniterative correlation-based tuning (nCbT) is a noniterative method for data-driven tuning of a fixed-structure controller that provides a one-shot method to directly synthesize a controller based on a single dataset.

## Intelligent Control Integration

Intelligent control is a class of control techniques that use various artificial intelligence computing approaches like neural networks, Bayesian probability, fuzzy logic, machine learning, reinforcement learning, evolutionary computation and genetic algorithms.

The search results show that machine learning and data-driven control represent important complementary approaches that reduce reliance on detailed mathematical models by leveraging experimental data and AI techniques.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
